Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Expanding the Tephrochronologic Record of the Northern Lesser Antilles Arc: Rapid Identification of Cryptotephra Using Multiple Methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
Explosive volcanic eruptions can disperse large amounts of pyroclastic material (tephra) over a wide geographic range. When preserved in the sedimentary record, these layers often serve as important stratigraphic marker beds that can be correlated spatially and temporally and related to the magnitude, source, and timing of eruptive activity. Sedimentological analysis of these deposits enable investigation of fundamental geologic questions related to arc generation, maintenance, and destruction processes. These include: (1) the rates, timing, frequency and magnitude of volcanic eruptions, 2) identification of systematic patterns or variance in the time series of volcanic eruptions in terms of eruptive style, eruption magnitude, and repose periods, (3) assessing the completeness of the onshore record, especially if the marine record contains events not archived onshore, and (4) the nature of volcanism during the construction of a volcanic complex (magma evolution, production rate, eruptive styles, spatio-temporal distribution of eruptive vents and products, and importance of constructional vs. destructional processes). This information is essential to inform assessments of present-day hazards from active arc volcanoes. However, while constraining the long term eruptive history of a volcanic arc before the start of written historical records or beyond well-preserved subaerial tephra fall deposits (often representing only a few thousand years) is important, it is inherently difficult.

Key to establishing an accurate geologic record is the development of a methodology capable of accurate, replicable, quantitative, and routine identification of these tephra layers in marine sediment sequences. Traditionally, tephrochronologic methods have been applied to visible tephra beds that are typically characterized by discrete, often dark-colored depositional layers. This limits tephrochronology studies to areas proximal to volcanic sources capable of producing voluminous deposits. Cryptotephras, fine layers of ash that may not be visible to the naked eye, may either represent smaller eruptions or eruptions from more distal sources. Identification of cryptotephra has now become essential in order to fully constrain the eruptive history of a volcanic center. Previously cryptotephra have been identified by a variety of time-intensive and destructive methods. The goal of this proposal is to document and characterize different sedimentary properties and semi-quantitatively identify the distribution and magnitude of cryptotephras in the sediment record at millimeter scale resolution from the surrounding sedimentary matrix using high resolution continuous scanning techniques. These techniques include: (1) magnetic measurements, particularly magnetic susceptibility; (2) reflectance spectroscopy; (3) core XRF scanning using the ITRAX system; and (4) Computer Tomography (CT) scans. While these four techniques have demonstrated their potential for the identification of tephra, they have rarely been used together, especially at the resolution required to document cryptotephra. Combining these three methodologies will provide a comprehensive assessment and evaluation of the sedimentological, geochemical, magnetic, and spectral properties of sediment, all of which have independently been shown to vary substantially with the presence of tephra and also allow evaluation of the efficacy of these techniques for cryptotephra identification. The described techniques will be applied to IODP cores drilled off Montserrat to establish a long term tephrochronologic record of Montserrat and to better constrain the evolution of the Lesser Antilles arc. This research will generate: (1) an expanded geologic history of the volcanic system driving Montserrat and an associated hazard assessment; (2) a better understanding of the evolution of the Lesser Antilles arc; and (3) an evaluation of a set of techniques that can be used to rapidly identify cryptotephra layers in sediment sequences by non-destructive means.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Volcanic hazards affect millions of people worldwide. Improved assessment, prediction, and mitigation of these hazards relies on our ability to better understand these systems. By identifying the timing, frequency, and magnitude of tephra (erupted volcanic products) deposits in the geological record we can potentially gain insights into the frequency and cyclicity of eruptions, the potential for specific systems to generate catastrophic events, and the underlying cause of the hazards. The onshore record of tephra close to the volcanic center is frequently where the thickest deposits occur, however, this record is often incomplete as surface processes erode these deposits away soon after eruption. In contrast, tephra is often carried into the ocean and incorporated into quasi-constantly accumulating marine sediments. These deposits are often smaller than those on land, and can be invisible to the naked eye (cryptotephra), however they are also the most complete records of volcanic histories. In this award we developed a method for rapidly and non-destructively identifying the presence of cryptotephra in the marine sediment record using a combination of techniques; magnetic susceptibility (sensitive to the iron-oxide content of tephra), visible/near-infrared spectroscopy (light reflectance bands sensitive to iron content of tephra), and X-ray fluorescence (sensitive to geochemical signatures of tephra) to discriminate between the tephra and the background ocean sediment. We applied this method to marine sediments recovered at Integrated Ocean Drilling Program (IODP) Site U1396, a 153 m sediment record spanning approximately 4.5 million years (Myrs) located 36 km southwest of the Soufriere Hills volcanic complex on the island of Montserrat. Our approach involved three phases; Phase 1 was concerned with developing the method and testing that our techniques were sensitive to tephra and could discriminate them from the surrounding sediment. Phase 2 involved testing this method by measuring the sediments deposited over the last 250 thousand years (kyrs) at Site U1396 and comparing them to a known tephra record from the region. During phase 3 we expanded the measurement of these techniques to identify tephra and thus establish the volcanic history over the full 4.5 Myr record.

It was often more efficient to group the implementation of phases 1 and 2 together. We made magnetic, reflectance, and XRF measurements at (sub)millimeter scale for the last 250 kyrs and between 1.9-2.5 Myrs and made magnetic and XRF measurements at the centimeter scale over the rest of the 4.5 Myr record. We were able to show that tephra contains several times the magnetic susceptibility values of the background sediment, that tephra have a unique fingerprint in the reflectance data, and that geochemical properties can easily distinguish between biogenic carbonate in the background sediment and layers enriched in iron, titanium, and aluminum that contain tephra. For the last 250 kyrs we combined these rapidly and non-destructively acquired datasets to identify 29 individual visible tephra and cryptotephra in the sediment record. We confirmed that these were not spurious results through traditional laborious and destructive petrological analyses that physically disaggregated the sediment to confirm the presence of volcanogenic grains under a microscope. The agreement between traditional and non-destructive scanning methods and our new record with previous results from the region were reported at scientific conferences in 2014 and 2015 and in a scientific publication in 2015. Phase three results are complete and were reported at a scientific conference at the end of 2016 and will be submitted for publication soon. Using the non-destructive parameters and differences in sediment density between tephra and the background sediment a ‘tephra-index’ was developed. This index was used to track the influx of tephra to the ocean over longer timescales. The key findings identified a cyclicity in volcanic activity in the Lesser Antilles over timescales of hundreds of thousands to millions of years that is consistent with melting in the mantle wedge and shorter term variations (in the order of tens of thousands of years) that are related to the life cycle of volcanic edifices. These results also extended our current knowledge of volcanism in the Lesser Antilles. The oldest rocks on Montserrat are dated to be approximately 2.1 Myrs old. This record revealed volcanic activity has existed in the region for at least 4.5 Myrs.

   One of the principal investigators of this award is an early career post-doctoral research associate thus the implementation and management of this award directly contributed to his professional development. The award also supported multiple undergraduate students in STEM fields at Tufts University and the University of Tennessee, three of whom are now enrolled in geology graduate programs. Results of this award have been presented to interested parties on the Island of Martinique in the Lesser Antilles in 2015 and have been the focus of five scientific conference presentations and one published journal article and two in preparation to be submitted in the near future.
